field_edited_text.value:
PRoOPOSED BRIDGE AT MILLERS ISLAND 133

mal to the axis of the channel, with a vertical clearance of 140 feet. The
span over the east channel provided for a lateral clearance of 636 feet, with
a vertical clearance of 140 feet. _

Following the submission of plans for this bridge, together with plans for
the other bridges, to the United States District Engineers’ Office in Balti-
more, for the approval of the War Department, J. E. Greiner Company
maintained contact with the office of the Chief of Engineers of the War
Department, in Washington, to determine what changes would be required
in the plans submitted, in order to meet all navigation requirements. The
Chief of Engineers had studied the navigation requirements for a bridge
across the Bay between Millers Island and Tolchester, and had determined
that the east end of the bridge would have to be shifted northerly, in
order to place the axis of the bridge on a line normal to the main
sailing course used by pilots in navigating the east channel of the Bay at
this point. Due to the broad expanse of open water, the Engineers of the
War Department determined that navigation of this channel would require
1,000 feet lateral clearance, with 140 feet vertical clearance, which is the
same vertical clearance as originally proposed and is the same as the maxi-
mum vertical clearance afforded by the existing lift bridges over the C.
& D. Canal.

Studies by the Engineers of the War Department, of the West channel
crossing diagonally under the bridge, from the mouth of the Patapsco River
to the vicinity of the western entrance to the C. & D. Canal, led to a de-
cision on the part of these Engineers that a span over this channel, if made
500 feet clear laterally and 50 feet high vertically, would be adequate for
the present and future navigation needs of this channel.

Upon consideration of the East Channel navigation requirements, it was
decided by the Engineers of the War Department to locate the channel
nearer to the Eastern shore, and to require a horizontal clearance of 1000
feet, with a vertical clearance of 140 feet. These changes greatly increase
the cost of the channel span, and also make necessary a long approach
trestle on shore.

In addition, it was thought advisable by the Engineers of the War De-
partment to require a drawspan in the trestle connecting the Western shore
and Hart Island, which would have 80 feet horizontal clearance and 15
feet vertical clearance, with span in closed position. This drawspan has
not been shown on Plate 84, but its cost has been included in Cost Estimate,
Table 76.

The above requirements were discussed informally, however, and were
